title: Between 1 January 2019 and 31 December 2019, how many reports of traffic accidents involving an autonomous vehicle will the California Department of Motor Vehicles receive?
preds: Think I count 100 (Dec 30) and question goes to Jan 17 to account for two week lag...so chance it could breach 115. Regardless thinking it will stay below 115
People seemed to doubt my thoughts about testing - and therefore accident - slowdown in December. ;)
Lest an additional 15 incidents are reported for the last 11 days of the year, this forecast is a certainty.
3 more added to the list for December, last dated Dec 19, taking the total to 84. Highly unlikely that the middle bucket will be exceeded.

No new updates since Nov 8, maybe an update this coming week will change my forecast.

Lowering "more than 115" for a possible December seasonal effect, I did not think about before.  Frequency of tests is likely to decline during the holiday season. During the 2018 there were less accident in December.

Between 1 January 2019 and 31 December 2019, how many reports of traffic accidents involving an autonomous vehicle will the California Department of Motor Vehicles receive?
No news is good news - widening my error bar a bit.

Up to november 8th: 84 
Direct extrapolation of the years average gives 102.6. 
Lower bound for a single month this year: 4 (January)
Last year: 3 (December) and 2 (February)
In order to make the third bucket, we would need to get this years lower bound twice in a row. I give this one percent and add another to account for unknown unknowns  Upper bound this year: 16. Given that there are only one and two third months left, this would have to be topped for two months in a row in order to reach 115. On one hand, this years maximum was reached in october, which might suggest a trend. And the last time the monthly count went over 10, this was followed by two months with an even higher count. On the other hand, the data seems to fluctuate a lot per month, so that it seems likely that october was an outlier. Furthermore, last december was the month with the second lowest amount of accidents in the previous year. Still, given the previous growth, topping the maximum twice seems more likely than not making it to the minimum twice. I give it 4%.

New data in.  With the surge back up towards the rates I was predicting, it should clear 95 without much problem.  However, though my predictions are flirting with 110, I'm hard pressed to give 115+ a lot of probability points.
We’re at 88 (I think) with about 8 weeks. Rough math points to 95-115 category.
Edit; I thought the last bin threshold was 105, not 115.
Appreciate the info from @nigster to get me properly framed to have a guess at this one. Given 88 so far, I'm projecting 12 / 10.5 months x 88 per 10.5 months to get 100.6 as a best guess.

https://www.cnbc.com/2019/11/08/alphabet-self-driving-car-company-waymo-shutters-austin-operations.html Interesting video showing whats it like to have hundreds of driverless cars.  On to analysis: Last 5 months, median of 11 per month.   This would put us smack dab at 110.
However, December (last year) revealed very few accidents perhaps due to low miles driven.
One could request re-release of 2018 data from  AVarchive@dmv.ca.gov.   Too much work. However, accidents this year are running substantially ahead of last year.    54/43 last 5 months.  Not an area I have special knowledge.  But the crowd forecasts are so far off.. it looks like free points.
With 88 reports thru end of October, it appears very likely that the fourth bucket will be it.

Nov and Dec have a lot of down time with the holidays when they may step down the testing, can't assume a steady rate each month is a sure bet. But last year's November was crowded with reports, so odds of 7 between now and end of Dec are pretty good.

Between 1 January 2019 and 31 December 2019, how many reports of traffic accidents involving an autonomous vehicle will the California Department of Motor Vehicles receive?  Tightening the range assuming fewer test drives means fewer accidents.

Reviewing past year data, I am starting to discount November 2018 as anomaly. If so, I'd expect very few accidents in November/December as it happened in all past years except Nov 2018. If I had to guess the narrative, Waymo and GM Cruise probably were rushing to fulfill (internal?) testing deadlines by end of 2018 and crammed a lot of testing into Nov 2018. Unless there's similar situation this year - and Oct data so far does not indicate it - we should expect the big Nov/Dec falloff that happened in previous years. Caveats: we don't know if any company has (internal) deadlines to do more testing this year before EOY; pre-2018 years had less testing overall and Nov/Dec falloff might not be comparable.  Keeping 95-115 bucket prediction up until we get data through end of October and maybe for part of Nov.
Maybe I'll hedge a bit.  This one has turned into a disaster for my predictions.

Can expect Dec to fall far short again with holidays, but it's a question of whether Oct-Dec will average more or less than 7.5 accidents/month. Winter months seem to have fewer accidents for whatever reason (suspect worse weather discourages as much testing). So far this year Jan-Mar have avg'd lower than that if looking at a 3-month block, Apr-Aug have avg'd higher. But there was also a spike in accidents last November. I'm betting on Nov and Dec looking more like Jan and Feb than the summer months.

Updating to include latest CA DMV data, minor updates to my method, & to give a review-breakdown of how I'm calculating this out & add a bit of forecast history (though I wish I'd tracked mine as well as @nigster. That level of detail would've been nice to reflect back on). Forecast: 96.4 accidents (SD 7.0)
Adjustment: [ -, -, +2, +1, -3 ] Accident Total Calculation:
Control Factors: [ (# of Miles Driven (est. & historical)), (Rate of Accidents for Auton. Vehicles (est. & historical)) ]
Inputs: [ (Rate of Accidents for Normal Vehicles), (Historical Data: Waymo/Cruise/Other Miles Driven), (Historical Data: Waymo/Cruise/Other Total Accidents) ] Latest Idealized Calculation Method (by Quarter): ((Est. Total Miles Driven) * (Est. Accident Rate (accidents per 100M-mi) ) ) / 100M
For Partial Quarters: (Accidents Reported) + ( (Latest Final Calculation Method) * ( (Days Remaining in Quarter) / (Days in Quarter Total) ) Extremized Upper Est.: (Total Acc. in 2019) + ((Remaining Est. Miles Driven) * (Accident Rate in Q4 2018))
Extremized Lower Est.: (Total Acc. in 2019) + ((Remaining Est. Miles Driven) * (Est Accident Rate in Q4 2019)) Final Calc: (2*(Estimated Total) + (Ext. Upper) + (Ext. Lower)) / 4 Forecast History:

Through September 10, 2019: (a) Waymo = 12, (b) Cruise = 40 and (c) All Other = 11. That said, Q3 ends Sep 30, so we have only seen about 75-80% of Q3, so we must adjust for days in Q. For Q4, we observe that Waymo had an anomalous Q2, so we throw it out of the data when making an extrapolation. We then must make assumptions for Q4 based on what we have seen for Waymo, GM and other, which gets us to our result. I have no idea how crowd is getting such weird numbers.

Avg monthly to reach more than 115: 11.8 I think I underestimated the increase in growth rate in my previous forecast, despite the discussion with @cafebedouin who pointed this out:
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/890096 It helps to spell out the average number of accidents that would lead to an outcome in the respective buckets. I think it is very unlikely that the remaining year will drop below the rolling 3 month average, taking us to the two highest buckets with >95% probability (if I had considered these numbers in my previous forecast I could have come to the same conclusion). As for the split between the highest and second highest bucket, I think it is more likely the 3mo rolling average will move up than move down. It would need to increase by 10% to reach the highest bucket, at the moment I think this is close to a coin toss, leaning slightly towards the lower bucket.

Revising my estimation method slightly to try and incorporate some suggestions from @cafebedouin & @nigster. I'm keeping my primary estimation (assumed mileage increase rate * assumed decreasing accident rate) but am now incorporating both a lower extremized total which uses the assumed end of year 2019 accident rate (16.88 APMm*) & and an upper extremized total which uses the end of year 2018 accident rate  (29.67 APMm) and then am bringing them back together in a weighted average (1:2:1). This yields the following range of estimates...
Lower Extreme: 85.8 accidents
Primary Estimate: 87.5 accidents
Upper Extreme: 106.1 accidents Resulatant Estimate: 91.7 accidents (93.1 unweighted)
SD: 11.25 This is a pretty sizeable increase from my last forecast (+7.3 accidents) but I do believe better reflects the story the data is telling.

Having now looked closer at the data, my main point forecast is 130 incidents. This is based on comparing the YTD growth rate for 2019 over 2018 and assuming the same growth by month for the full year.  Incidents for the month of August have been higher compared to July for each year since the start of data capture in 2015. Assuming zero growth for the remaining months of this year compared to 2018, thus seems too conservative, yet would give a point forecast of 94.  For that reason the bulk, if not all of the probability mass should be assigned to the two highest categories in my view, with '115+' being by far the most likely scenario.

Affirming. Y'all are crazy! Let me give you the argument why you should be most heavily weighted in the top tier: If you do something simple, like take actual per month accident incidence, only ~30% happen January to May. Total is 27 so far, so easy linear calculation is 27/0.33 = ~82. But, this curve is growing. If you do last year from beginning of year to May 21 / May 25, it's 15 or 20. Even using 20 because of the cluster of accidents in the May 21-25 period, it's still a 35% increase, which will still get you over a 100. Assume 80%, 27/15 = 1.8 or an 80% increase, and you're getting near 137. If you using the part of the year with the fewest accidents to forecast for the rest of the year on a curve that's growing, it's going to be higher on the range, and you only need 52% growth for the year to be +115. You are doing linear progression on an exponential curve, ladies and gents.
The number of accidents so far in May further reduces the likelihood that this year's number will be lower than last year's of 75.

Twenty-eight companies actively tested 467 self-driving vehicles on public roads in California last year. Those vehicles covered 2,036,296 miles in autonomous mode.[1] The companies reported 143,720 disengagements. That’s the number of times the system had to turn control back to a human driver. As Statista explained, “Disengagements are a key part of the testing process and they occur when a car's software detects a failure or a driver perceives a failure, resulting in control being seized.”[2] Google’s Waymo cars had the best track record, going an average of 11,154 miles between disengagements. GM Cruise was the only other company to average more than 5,000 miles before giving control back to the humans. The worst performers during this period were Apple and Uber. The two of them combined accounted for 97% of all reported disengagements. Apple averaged just 1.1 miles between disengagements. For Uber, the average was less than half a mile.

The history from https://www.dmv.ca.gov/portal/dmv/detail/vr/autonomous/autonomousveh_ol316 looks like this:
 2014: 1 report
 2015: 9 reports
 2016: 15 reports
 2017: 29 reports
 2018: 75 reports
 (2019: 4 so far)
This looks like an exponential curve, which is typical of the growth rate of a new technology (I'm happy to assume that the number of accidents reported is closely coupled with the total number of autonomous vehicles on the road, at least on short time scales, and ignore the possibility of changes in the accident or reporting rates). Using http://www.lelandstanfordjunior.com/quickfit.html, assuming that `y = pow(a, x + b)` with starting values `a = 2` and `b = -2000`, we get a curve of approximately `y = pow(2.339, x - 2013)` (i.e. more than doubling each year).  At `x = 2019` the curve gives 174 accidents. This is far enough into the 'More than 115' category that I don't think I need to worry about error in the curve or small sources of noise.  However there are unexpected events that could change the pattern entirely (such as changes in the law), and the rest of my prediction is an attempt to account for that.

I start with a simple model of the influencing variables and make a lot of rough assumptions in the spirit of the Fermi-izing method to get a rough idea of the expected number and uncertainties. ~~~
Conclusion
~~~
The expected distribution for the 2019 number is centered close to the 2018 number of accidents, which is ~70. Two counteracting sets of forces: i) increase in miles driven and ii) increasing share of Non-waymo vehicles with higher accident rates VS. iii) improvements in miles per accident ~~~
Discussion:
~~~ Accidents are a function of: [ miles traveled by company i ] x 1 / [ miles per accident by company i ] summed across all companies i. For simplicity, I divide companies by two categories: Waymo and Non-Waymo. This distinction serves our purposes because Waymo represents more than half of miles driven [1] and because there is a stark distinction between miles per accident for Waymo (much better) and other companies. Let's take all assumptions one at a time:
1) miles driven: for simplicity I am looking at this number across all companies. It was ~650k in 2016 and ~500k in 2017. Given the exponential nature of this variable, a reasonable assumption may be that the number will double in 2018 and double again in 2019: i.e. 2 million miles in 2019. Caveat: companies moving to Arizona will put downward pressure on this number. 2) miles per accident: Waymo weighted average is around 48. Non-waymo weighted average is around 6 [2]. It is reasonable to assume some improvement. For now, I'd say 10% for Waymo and 150% for Non-Waymo given that they have a lot to improve.  3) company shares: We also have to assume how the shares of miles driven will change. I assume that non-Waymo will grow to 45% of miles driven. In 2017, Waymo was 70% [1] - I expect this number to go down but not by much given that Waymo maintains heavily invested and benefits from its past experience, which allows it to retain a dominant position at least in the short term. Result: 81 accidents.  Sensitivities: 
-the improvement in miles per accident for Non-waymo is an important variable. A 200% improvement drops the final number to 71.
-miles driven is also very important. If we saw 3 million miles driven, the final number jumps to 121.
-share of non-waymo miles driven is less significant but still somewhat important. [1] https://www.theverge.com/2018/1/31/16956902/california-dmv-self-driving-car-disengagement-2017
[2] https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5607180/

This is a much harder question than it appears. Partially because the question is not well defined and partially because it is not a static situation. The question does not state what Level of autonomy we are judging. There are 5 levels from something like enhanced cruise-control to fully autonomous. There is also the vagueness in the question regarding "testing" autonomous vehicles versus consumer autonomous vehicles. For example, there are no Level 5 consumer vehicles on the road, but there are several companies testing Level 5 vehicles on the roads in CA. This is also a moving target. The number of accidents for 2017 might be radically different thant the number of accidents for 2019, because teh number of companies entering the market is increasing. And different manufacturers have different track records for percent of accidents reported. Google has few, BMW has more since they just got in the game. That said, I looked at the data I could find and I think the proposed answer possibilities are low. I think there is this idea that autonomous vehicles are never involved in accidents. But you have to consider accidents caused by other drivers as well. For example, autonomous vehicles notoriously hesitate when entering trraffic, and they get rear-ended a lot. That is an accident. The question doesn't state that the autonomous vehicle caused the accident. The below report link goes into depth about the correlation between miles driven and accidents, and if I could find more data about accidents in general in CA for conventional cars then I could provide a decent statistical number of expected autonomous accidents - with the assumption that "autonomous" in this question means any Level of autonomy. Miles driven per accident reported:
The PLoS One paper (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5607180/) cites 40-54k miles driven per accident for Google's vehicles, see Table 2. Other companies do much worse with 3k-20k miles driven per accident. A pessimistic outlook for this parameter would be: 
- no progress from Google/Waymo, so they would remain at ~50k miles driven per accident. 
- the rest of the pack manages to catch up to the best from the paper, so the rest has an accident every 20k miles driven.
An optimistic outlook for this parameter would be:
- Google/Waymo manages to beat the average of conventional cars in the US (500k miles/accident). Considering they want to launch a commercial service, they pretty much have to be measured by that standard in order to gain their customers' trust.
- The rest catches up halfway, so 250k miles/accident. There is a fair chance they might get better even faster, as once a pioneer has led the way it's easier for competitors to follow, poach people who have know how from a project that succeeded, etc. This technology might be starting to take off exponentially, which is always hard to wrap one's head around in a forecast. Also let's also assume that half the miles driven in CA will be Waymo, and the other half will be the rest. So far, we then get:
lower bound: 1M miles driven / 375k miles driven per accident --> 3 accidents (this sounds way too optimistic now) 
upper bound: 3M miles driven / 35k miles driven per accident --> 85 accidents Considering the DMV already listed 60 accidents in 2018 so far, we might get up to 70-80 in 2018 in total.  Knowing that my calibration tends to be narrow, going to spread my forecast out quite a bit across the bins (with slight slant towards more accidents) until some more information emerges, such as:
- miles driven in CA in 2018
- projected miles for 2019
- details about commercial ventures to be launched
